11/3/22    On 17th February most restrictions were lifted by the federal government    Masks  In enclosed areas of public vehicles as well as in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospitals and clinics, retirement and care homes, people age 12 and over must wear masks. Youâll find more detailed information on the Masks page.    Wearing of masks compulsory throughout Switzerland  The mask-wearing requirement applies throughout Switzerland on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. Besides the nationwide rules, the cantons can make wearing masks compulsory in additional areas and situations. For this reason you must always follow the cantonal rules.   Wearing of masks compulsory on public transport and on planes  You must wear a mask in enclosed areas of the following public transport services and facilities:  Trains, trams and buses  Mountain railways, cable cars and chair lifts  Ships and boats  Aircraft (all scheduled and chartered flights taking off or landing in Switzerland)  Note: Masks are compulsory at all times, no matter how many people are travelling. If you refuse to wear a mask on public transport, you may be asked by the transport staff to get off at the next stop. If you refuse to do so, you may receive a fine. You may remove your mask briefly to eat or drink on public transport.     Wearing of masks compulsory in publicly accessible areas  To protect particularly vulnerable people, in certain situations masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospital, clinics, retirement and care homes.   Wearing of masks compulsory at work  Your employer has a duty to protect you. For this reason you should find out from your employer what requirements apply in terms of mask-wearing. You will find more information on the SECO website (in German).  Exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask  Children under the age of 12 do not have to wear a mask (cantonal exemptions may apply). Masks are available in childrenâs sizes. Adult masks can also be folded and the straps shortened to fit childrenâs faces (recommended for surgical masks).  General exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. In the following cases, you do not have to wear a mask (regardless of your age):  You can prove that you are unable to wear a mask for a specific reason. Such reasons include, for example, facial injuries, shortness of breath, conditions such as dementia and Alzheimerâs, anxiety when wearing a mask and disabilities that make wearing a mask intolerable or impossible. All medical grounds must be substantiated with a certificate from a doctor or psychotherapist. You will find detailed information in the factsheet from the FBED and FOPH on mask dispensing for certain people with disabilities in the Documents tab.  You are a patient in a hospital or clinic: You can take off your mask when you are in your room(s).  You are resident in a retirement or care home.  Masks in everyday life  In any situation in which you want to give yourself and others additional protection you can decide for yourself whether you want to wear a mask even if doing so is not compulsory. Itâs still recommended to wear a mask particularly in enclosed and poorly ventilated spaces.    https://archive.fo/yREMb

https://archive.ph/ML7FX#selection-143.15-147.20  A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern). Transport companies, e.g. air carriers and railway companies, may not transport any persons from these countries to Germany. There are only a few, strictly defined exceptions to this travel ban, namely for:  German citizens and persons who are resident in Germany with a current right to reside in the country, as well as their spouses, partners (if entering Germany from outside the EU or the United Kingdom / Northern Ireland: only partners living in the same household) and minor children  persons catching a connecting flight who do not leave the transit zone of a passenger airport and  few other special cases.  Persons qualifying for these exceptions must nevertheless complete a digital entry registration before entering the country, undergo mandatory testing or provide proof of immunity, and comply with the applicable quarantine regulations for travellers entering the country.

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services. If you have had close contact with a COVID-19 case and you are not vaccinated with a complete vaccination regimen, you should quarantine: if you have had close contact with a patient with COVID-19 or someone suspected of having it without adequate protective measures, from 48 hours before the onset of symptoms, you should quarantine for 7 days staying in your home or place of accommodation, preferably in a room on your own. During the following 10 days after the last contact, protection measures should be stepped up (use of masks, limiting the number of social contacts, etc).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220311053730/https://www.spth.gob.es/faq?tab=2

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organizer ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask

On March 15th it appears that all restrictions on gathering have been lifted.  Social distancing guidelines such as dispersion and medical grade facemasks are the only requirement currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321211225/https://kriis.ee/uudised/valitsus-kaotab-homsest-covidi-toendi-kontrollikohustuse-ja-kella-23-sulgemispiirangu  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215758/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/culture-and-entertainment  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321194839/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#stores

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit). Those who are fully vaccinated are exempt from these measures.    There's no particular testing or quarantine requirement for vaccinated persons / persons who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 disease.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220318140804/https://kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions

Estonian citizens and residents are allowed into the country regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not.  Entry into Estonia for the purposes of work, studying, tourism, sports etc is also allowed for the citizens of other countries (both European Union and third countriesâ). The citizens of third countries have to have a valid Schengen visa in order to be able to enter the country.  In certain cases, including those without vaccination certificate, recovery certificate, or a negative COVID-19 test, it is obligatory to stay in self-isolation after entering the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403110543/https://kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/coming-estonia  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403105151/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#entry

There is income support for all workers available to them on the second day of sickness, first day is not paid.  They will be paid by their employer according to the average wages of the employee.  Additionally, after the 6th day, benefits are paid by the Health Insurance Fund according to employee's daily income.  Additionally, there are benefits for parents of children where they get 14 days of sick time to care of the child and up to 80% of the persons wages are paid.       https://web.archive.org/web/20220315115525/https://kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/sick-days-certificates-care-leave#care-allowance

In order to reduce the risk of people falling ill at work and the deductible of employees, and thereby limit the spread of COVID-19, the procedure for reimbursing sick leaves was temporarily changed from 01.01.2021. The employee's deductible is the first day of illness, the employer pays the benefit from the second to the fifth day and the health insurance fund pays the benefit from the sixth day. This compensation procedure will continue in 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220403112137/https://kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/sick-days-certificates-care-leave  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403112132/https://haigekassa.ee/inimesele/haigekassa-huvitised/haigushuvitis-01012021-31122022

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all staff of medical and medico-social institutions (including administrative staff), supporting services, and those who work in contact with frail people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No change in policy, in addition to policies affecting the general population it remains a requirement that all people working with elderly people are fully vaccinated as a condition of employment. The vaccine pass remains mandatory to access elderly home care centres.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Any citizen/resident of a foreign country may enter Georgia through air, land or marine borders from March 1, 2022 if fully vaccinated. Unvaccinated individuals needs to present a PCR test valid for 72 hours (without an obligation of getting re-tested with PCR on the third day); So-called country locks are vanishing.  https://archive.ph/jEsvY

All citizens of foreign countries will be admitted to Georgia via air, land, and marine borders provided they are fully vaccinated (two full doses, except only one is required for Johnson & Johnson) or have a negative PCR test result (administered 72 hours or less before arrival in Georgia).  There is no obligation to self isolate, or for unvaccinated individuals to get re-tested on the third day after arrival, or to complete an application form. More information is available here.  Travelers under the age of 10 are exempt from the obligation to provide a vaccination certificate or negative PCR test.  https://archive.ph/aV68A

All family members living with the coronavirus positive person should stay in isolation. Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you are an other contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  https://archive.ph/PzGwC

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  https://archive.ph/tPCET

Domestic travel in Greenland:  Face masks  -It is not a requirement to wear a face mask on Air Greenland domestic flights in Greenland. However, the authorities recommend that all domestic travellers over the age of 12 wear a face mask or visor that covers both nose and mouth.  Last updated Wednesday 16. february  https://archive.ph/0fqpG    Use of face masks and visors:  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222044950/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215030314/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

No policy change.  Physical distance, hygiene, and other preventative measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403223541/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uploads/Upute_za_sprjecavanje_i_suzbijanje_epidemije_bolesti_COVID_19_vezano_uz_rad_predskolskih_ustanova_osnovnih_i_srednjih_skola_u_skolskoj_godini_2021_2022_3_75c63541db.pdf

No policy change.  In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interfering with workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403224542/https://koronavirus.hr/o-poslu/46

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    It is mandatory to use a face mask indoors and when it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 1.5 m outdoors. The obligation to use the mask does not apply to visitors during the consumption of food and beverages, nor to contractors during the performance.    It is obligatory to adhere to the measure of physical distancing which avoids close personal contact at a distance of at least 1.5 meters outdoors and 2 meters indoors. It is not necessary for people living in a joint household to maintain the prescribed distance. The distance between the visitor and the performer on stage must be at least 4 meters.     The physical distance between visitors during the program, the organizer must provide seats 1.5 meters apart  Exceptionally, when holding performances, cultural programs and low-risk events, the physical distance between visitors from 1 seat is allowed, with the obligatory wearing of masks during the program. The restriction does not apply to visitors living in the same household. Low-risk programs are programs with exclusively seating places that do not involve interaction with the audience and active engagement of the audience such as singing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403225317/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

No limitation if everyone attending has a digital COVID-19 certificate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change.  A negative viral test result: PCR not older than 72 hours or rapid antigen test (list of acceptable antigen tests) not older than 48 hours (counting from the time of taking the test to arriving at the border crossing point).  A certificate showing they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate showing they have received a single doze of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single doze not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since the single doze, or a certificate that they have received the booster doze of the vaccine.  A certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point.  A positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days, and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or a medical certificate of recovery.  Perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing immediately upon arrival to Croatia (at the travelerâs own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until receiving a negative test result. If testing cannot be performed, travelers must self-isolate for a period of 10 days.  Travelers can facilitate faster processing at the Croatian border by completing the Enter Croatia web form and uploading their information and attachments ahead of their arrival.  Tourists are also required to show the proof of booked or paid accommodation or ownership of a home or a vessel when entering Croatia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence of income support.
No evidence of debt/contract relief.

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Updated March 17: New measures have been announced to address the elderly population, which is also the most vulnerable. Follow these pages, we will publish them as soon as they are official.    The most effective general prevention measures:  frequent hand hygiene with products containing 70% alcohol: rub your hands if your hands are invisibly dirty or wash with soap and water if your hands are dirty for about 20 seconds  avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth  maintain air hygiene by coughing or sneezing into a bent elbow or tissue and then immediately throw the tissue in the trash can with a lid  wearing a medical mask is mandatory if you have respiratory symptoms  after removing the mask from the face it is mandatory to carry out hand hygiene  maintaining a distance in social contact between persons of at least 1 meter if the person has any of the respiratory symptoms  maintain the hygiene of your living space by periodically wiping surfaces that are frequently touched with your hands with a surface disinfectant     https://web.archive.org/web/20220403232847/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-prevenciji/vazne-upute-za-starije-osobe-i-kronicne-bolesnike/51

Protect yourself and others from COVID-19    If you have any symptoms of COVID-19, even mild ones, you should:    - self-isolate (stay in your room) until 48 hours after your symptoms are mostly or fully gone  - wear a face mask if you have to be around other people    Do these even if you completed your first round of COVID-19 vaccination, had a booster, or had COVID-19 in the past.    Do    - get a COVID-19 vaccine and booster dose when it's available to you    - keep at least 2 metres (around 6 feet) away from people you do not live with    - wash your hands properly and often    - wear a face mask in crowded places outdoors and when you move around in public indoor spaces    - cover coughs or sneezes with a tissue or your sleeve - put used tissues into a bin and wash your hands    - meet people outdoors where possible    - try to avoid crowded places where you cannot keep a distance from people - there's a greater risk of infection in crowded and enclosed places    - check that visitors to your home or workplace do not have symptoms of COVID-19, colds or flu    - let fresh air into your home by opening windows, doors and air vents as much as possible when you have visitors    - clean objects and surfaces that other people touch      Don't    - do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth if your hands are not clean    - do not share objects that touch your mouth, for example, bottles or cups    - do not shake hands or make close contact with other people, if possible    - do not wear gloves instead of washing your hands - your hands can get contaminated when you take them off    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319141023/https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/covid19/preventing-the-spread/protect-yourself-and-others/

From 6 March 2022, all COVID-19 travel restrictions are removed. You no longer need to complete a passenger locator form. You also no longer need proof of vaccination or recovery, or a COVID-19 test.    You should follow public health advice if you develop symptoms of COVID-19 or if you are a close contact of a confirmed case of COVID-19.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220308070549/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.html

Green passes are required only for university students: for university students that are non-vaccinated, there is a requirement to show a negative-test or a certification that they recently recovered from Covid. For unvaccinated university students school is otherwise closed.  For vaccinated students masks and social distancing (desks/seats 1m apart) are still required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307090518/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

A Super Green pass is mandatory to all workers 50+ and for some additional workers categories, irrespective of age. Such workplaces are virtually closed for those who are not vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid.  All other workers still need a Green Pass.  In all cases, masks and social distancing still are enforced at work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307090518/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

In order to enter a non-essential business, a green pass or super green pass is required.  A Super Green pass is mandatory to all workers 50+ and for some additional workers categories, irrespective of age. Such workplaces are virtually closed for those who are not vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid.  All other workers still need a Green Pass.  In all cases, masks and social distancing still are enforced at work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320203534/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

From Jan 10th  for local public transport for everyone 12+ directives require travelers to exhibit a Super Green Pass (as a proof of vaccination or being recovered from Covid).  Capacity is still reduced to 80% for most types of transport and FFP2 masks are required for all travellers irrespective of vaccination status.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216150703/https://www.autoblog.it/post/stato-demergenza-fino-al-31-marzo-2022-super-green-pass-le-regole-per-i-trasporti  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307090518/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

No Orange Zones from Feb 28th. The number of white regions is increasing as yellow regions are decreasing.  Social distancing and masks in closed spaces are mandatory anywhere for everyone, including the vaccinated.  For regions that are classified as Yellow or White zones no curfews are in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220310112311/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638  https://web.archive.org/web/20220312104021/https://www.qualitytravel.it/colori-regioni-covid-19-le-nuove-zone-rosse-arancioni-gialle-e-bianche-dal-22-marzo/92843https://web.archive.org/web/20220307090518/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

From April 1st the emergency status has been removed, and zone-differentiated policies are removed too, hence no restrictions for internal movement exist    https://web.archive.org/web/20220401074145/https://www.gazzetta.it/salute/01-04-2022/covid-nuove-regole-aprile-2022-piscine-palestre-lavoro-green-pass-mascherine.shtml

From March 1st almost all travel restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

Vaccine mandates are in place for:  - all school & university personnel (including teachers)  - everyone 50+ (from Jan 8th)  - healthcare workers (everyone working in healthcare facilities, so this is not limited to nurses and doctors)  - long term care facilities personnel  - law enforcement and public rescue personnel, jail guards and public cybersecurity personnel (as they are still military personnel)    It is clearly stated at the following link that the vaccine mandate is for everyone 50+, not just workers. At the same link, you can find a detailed list of the categories for which a mandate is in place: https://web.archive.org/web/20220311173308/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5452&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto    The mandate is **NOT** in place for taxi drivers, private security guards or government officials. For such categories the general green pass requirement is in place (which is not a vaccine mandate)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222164937/https://www.fiscoetasse.com/rassegna-stampa/31598-obbligo-vaccinale-e-terza-dose-le-nuove-categorie-interessate-dal-1512.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211214656/https://www.ipsoa.it/documents/impresa/contratti-dimpresa/quotidiano/2022/01/08/covid-19-vigore-8-gennaio-obbligo-vaccinale-cinquantenni

No changes found    Archive Link   https://web.archive.org/web/20220405041414/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-domestic-measures-as-of-march-4-update-53
Quote "Red: movement restricted to self-isolation regime"    Archive Link   https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "Is a curfew in place?  No.    Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system (please see further information on âAshyqâ in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstanâs regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "To enter Kazakhstan, international arrivals generally must provide evidence of a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival. Travelers with a valid vaccination certificate are exempt from the testing requirement. This pre-travel testing requirement does not apply to children under five years of age, Kazakhstani government delegations, and cabin crew."    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220405041414/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-domestic-measures-as-of-march-4-update-53  ___________________________________________  Quote: "The Government of Kazakhstan requires foreign travelers arriving in Kazakhstan to provide a negative COVID-19 PCR test with results dated no more than three days prior to their entry to Kazakhstan.  If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry.  The following are exempt: children under age five, Kazakhstani Government delegations, and cabin crew.  In addition, each traveler must undergo a temperature check and fill out a questionnaire on prior travel, potential COVID-19 exposure, and contact information. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found

Quote: "Masks Required: The Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan has recommended that masks be worn nationwide in public settings, including both indoor and outdoor spaces and on public transportation, but the requirement to wear masks in most places has been lifted. "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: "Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac, Sinopharm, and Pfizer. Pfizer vaccinations may not be available to non-Kazakhstani citizens. Please check with your local provider.  Foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  "    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404122416/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

It is possible to apply for and receive short-time work compensation due to the economic consequences of the pandemic. This is officially in place until the end of March 2022, with the possibility of extension until June 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305143517/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/medienmitteilungen/moeglichkeit-fuer-corona-bedingte-kurzarbeitsentschaedigung-soll-bis-juni-2022-verlaengert-werden & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305144018/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-84116.html

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220319220909/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: https://archive.ph/eS2Kd & https://archive.ph/bTxvL

Residents aged 5 and over can register for vaccination, with booster vaccines available for all those 12 and over. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being used.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140637/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/coronavirus & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305141510/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/privatpersonen/gesundheit-vorsorge-und-pflege/coronavirus/anmeldung-covid-impfung

Per changes on March 1st, individuals attending school are no longer required to have covid passport or overload certificate. (Rules still apply to adults over the age of 18 attending school.)  However, educators and staff are required to have vaccination certificate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220321164223/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/nosacijumi-pakalpojumu-sniegsanai-un-tirdzniecibai-no-1-marta  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19

Employees involved in the study process must have a vaccination or recovery certificate. Pupils and students at all levels can study in person without any preconditions or facemasks wearing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Some sectors require the vaccine, such as healthcare providers, long-erm social care services, prison staff, people who provide public services with direct contact with recipient of services.  There is a general recommendation to work from home if possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321164223/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/nosacijumi-pakalpojumu-sniegsanai-un-tirdzniecibai-no-1-marta  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19

Persons without a vaccination or recovery certificate can perform the work on-site.  The following persons must have a primary vaccination or recovery certificate:      - Employees of medical institutions in direct contact with patients,  Employees of educational institutions in direct contact with learners.  Remote work is recommended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Per the updated mandate on March 1st, both vaccinated and unvaccinated can attend indoor/outdoor events with a medical grade facemask, with a maximum of 3000 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana

All cultural sites are accessible to everyone without space restrictions and other safety requirements.  There are no restrictions on organising events.  Event organisers and service providers have the right to set epidemiological safety requirements when assessing risks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

All persons are restricted to up to 50 people for private events and up to 250 people for baptisms, weddings and funerals.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana
There are no restrictions on the number of people gathering.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Medical grade or respirators without valve are required on public transportation.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana
https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

The March 1 mandate mainly focused on lifting restrictions for services provided to non-vaccinated persons.  Services can be provided as long as 15 m between visitors can be maintained.  Government is targeting April 1 for further lifting of restrictions.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321164223/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/nosacijumi-pakalpojumu-sniegsanai-un-tirdzniecibai-no-1-marta  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19

https://web.archive.org/web/20220402112148/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

One of the following are required.  Valid vaccination certificate, or nevagtive proof of covid (RNA 72 hrs, Antigen 48 hrs)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152321/https://covid19.gov.lv/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ka-drosi-rikoties/covid-19-izplatibas-ierobezosanas-pasakumi  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321152408/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates-par-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321153038/https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/sertifikatu-veidi-un-izmantosana

11/3/22  Masks must be worn in enclosed spaces throughout Poland    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

18/3/22  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/2022031

1/4/22    No change but from 28th March the requirement to isolate and wear masks has been abolished apart from medical institutes and pharmacies.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

11/3/22  You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308150404/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

11/3/22  Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

1/4/22  From April 1, 2022, the rules for ordering and performing coronavirus tests will change.  Your doctor will decide to refer you for a coronavirus test based on an assessment of your health, including symptoms that may indicate COVID-19. .  If a GP decides to test a patient with disturbing symptoms, it will be a rapid antigen test. The test result is known after a few or several minutes. The test will be free for the patient.  A PCR test may be ordered by your doctor prior to admission to hospital if deemed necessary. The PCR test will be used in the event of definitive confirmation or exclusion of whether the symptoms of respiratory tract infections with which the patient entered the hospital are caused by the coronavirus.  In the case of a positive SARS-CoV-2 test result, the doctor recommends self-isolation (sick leave) until symptoms disappear. Just like any infectious disease, such as the flu.  The length of the sick leave depends on the doctor (minimum 7 days recommended), depending on the patient's condition, risk factors for the severe course of the COVID-19 disease (e.g. lack of vaccination against COVID-19, advanced age, chronic diseases, e.g. diabetes) and high risk the occurrence of complications.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

11/3/22  Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

1/4/22  I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  Not. The so-called quarantine from contact.     Important! If you know that you have had close contact with an infected or sick person and you develop symptoms - take the test .    A test referral means an automatic quarantine that will end if you test negative. Quarantine does not apply to tests performed privately. A positive test result always requires isolation for 7 days.    Check the test result in the Internet Patient Account !    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

11/3/22  Masks must be worn in enclosed spaces throughout Poland    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

1/4/22  Social distance and face masks  From Monday (March 28, 2022) the obligation to wear masks has been abolished.    The exception applies to medical entities and pharmacies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328131536/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

11/3/22  We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

1/4/22  No change  How to get vaccinated?  The pass for vaccination is e-referral. Currently, children from 5 years of age can get vaccinated. There are a few basic rules to follow right before vaccination. Read on for details.    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  mojeIKP - mobile application,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     Register for vaccination - find out the details    How to prepare for vaccinations *?    Get enough sleep before vaccination - sleep has a positive effect on the immune system.  Limit alcohol - a few days before vaccination, but also after taking the preparation, reduce the amount, and preferably do not consume alcohol at all.  Be physically active before vaccination - exercise improves your body's performance.  You do not need to fast before having the vaccine - eat all meals as normal on the day of vaccination.  Do not stop taking the medications you regularly take on your own - consult your doctor.  Carefully complete the pre-vaccination questionnaire - you will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire before taking the preparation. Don't withhold any information!  Wait after vaccination at the vaccination site of min . 15 minutes - it's for your safety.  Do not be afraid of NOP - it is short for undesirable vaccine reactions. They are mostly mild and rare. It may happen that after receiving the vaccine you will have, for example, redness at the injection site or a mild fever. These symptoms should disappear within 1-3 days. If you are more uncomfortable, you can take an anti-pyretic drug after vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

Are vaccinations voluntary?  Vaccination is voluntary, except for healthcare professionals, pharmacists, medical students and healthcare professionals who must be fully vaccinated by March 1, 2022. We encourage other people to vaccinate against COVID-19. The more people get vaccinated, the more effective protection against the coronavirus will be.     https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

11.	The learning and teaching process in pre-school and daycare institutions shall take place according to the recommendations for pre-school institutions of NIPHK dated 20.01.2022.      12.	The learning and teaching process in all pre-university education institutions of all levels, as well as in daycare centres shall take place in accordance with the MEST Guidelines for the organization of the educational process in the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic. The task forces of the educational institutions decide on the application of scenarios for the organization of the teaching process, depending on the situation in the institution and in the classrooms.    13.	The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of the space.     14.	Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be allowed registration to the dormitory.    15.	Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the institution.    16.	Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     17.	The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of each institution according to points 14, 15 and 16, is obliged by decision to appoint one or more responsible persons who will control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

4.	All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  4.2	Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

F. [Restriction of public and private gatherings]     19.	Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to 50% of capacities (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the relevant evidence, such as:      19.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  19.2	Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which should not be older than 48 hours;  19.3	Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.  19.4	Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days).    20.	Meetings of the Assembly and Government are allowed regardless of the number of persons, respecting the wearing of masks and maintaining the physical distance of 1 (one) meter between persons.      21.	The Emergency Operational Centre of the Ministry of Health may issue a special permit, exceeding 50% of capacities, for events of special importance in the function of public interest.    22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    23.	Religious ceremonies and rites are allowed to carry out their activity up to 50% of the utilizing capacity, provided that they possess any of the evidence according to points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter the indoor spaces, in accordance with the relevant instruction, except participants under the age of 12.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Transportation Options  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Reduced levels of commercial flights are available, but schedules change frequently so we recommend you check with the airline and/or travel agency for regular updates.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

No more curfew     Movement Restrictions  Is a curfew in place? No.  For access to all public institutions, malls and dining inside restaurants, customers are obliged to possess evidence of vaccination, a negative PRC or rapid negative antigen test.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Public transport is allowed to operate.  Taxis are allowed to work.  Wearing a mask is mandatory when indoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Entry and Exit Requirements  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Varies (see below)  As of March 1, 2022, every person who enters Kosovo must produce one of the following:  Full vaccination certificate with two (2) doses (or a single-dose of Janssen vaccine) not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last dose;  Vaccination certificate with a single dose, together with a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  This requirement does not apply to children under the age of 12. Children from 12 to 16 years of age must have a negative RT-PCR test not older than 48 hours.    Airlines, transit points, and destination countries impose a patchwork of different testing requirements and airlines may refuse boarding for some passengers (including U.S. citizens and Kosovo residents). Airlines have the sole authority to decide who they allow to board their aircraft. Generally, pre-travel testing is recommended.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Pristina International Airport is open to travelers.  Check with the airlines, airports, and the U.S. Embassies located in your countries of transit to verify entry/exit requirements and be aware that they change frequently.    Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes â self quarantine.  Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent resident permits, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess the evidence required above and seek to enter the country are obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of income support.
No evidence of debt/contract relief.
o change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211007101425/https://msh.rks-gov.net/en/

esting available across Kosovo    COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html   If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratori I Mikrobiologis e Klinike, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101164843/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of contact tracing.

Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    From October 25, 2021 to April 1, 2022, metropolitan enterprises must transfer to remote work:  at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  all workers over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. An exception is only for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.    In addition, in organizations where possible, it is recommended to transfer the maximum number of people to a remote mode of work.    Russia's Labor Ministry has recommended that all enterprises send as many of their employees to remote work as possible due to the surge in Covid-19 cases.    Previous archives:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218140404/https://tass.ru/obschestvo/13583061

Event organizers with less than 500 attendees are encouraged to make similar decisions.  Previous archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/    QR codes may be required to access venues such as museums, theatres, stadiums, shopping centres or restaurants. QR codes are typically issued to those either vaccinated with a Russian vaccine, recently recovered from COVID-19 or with a recent negative PCR test. Requirements and procedures for obtaining QR codes vary depending on the region. Foreign nationals may not be required to have a QR code if they present a documentary proof of full vaccination by a Russian vaccine.
