Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Following widespread reports of military activity in Ukraine, on 24 February the Russian authorities announced restrictions on domestic flights to a number of airports in southern Russia, with disruption to internal flights to and from Moscow and other cities. The restrictions are set to be in place until 2 March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230219/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/coronavirus

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes, some regions may require tourists to show evidence of vaccination. Generally, Russian authorities will only accept evidence of vaccination with one of the vaccines registered in the Russian Federation. The Moderna, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are not currently registered in the Russian Federation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220401175247/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On 18 March 2020 the Russian government introduced restrictions on entry into the whole country for almost all foreign citizens. On 30 March 2020, temporary restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders were enforced. The duration of these remains unspecified.    These restrictions were eased on 16 April 2021 for nationals and permanent residents of certain countries including the UK. They may now travel to Russia by air via authorised 3rd countries. The full list is subject to change and currently includes Albania; Andorra; Argentina; Armenia; Austria; Azerbaijan; Bahamas; Bahrain; Bangladesh; Belgium; Brazil; Bulgaria; China; Columbia; Costa Rica; Croatia; Cuba; Cyprus; Czech Republic; Denmark; Djibouti; Dominican Republic; Egypt; Ethiopia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Iceland; India; Indonesia; Iran; Iraq; Italy; Japan; Jordan; Kazakhstan; Kenya; Kuwait; Kyrgyzstan; Lebanon; Lichtenstein; Luxemburg; Maldives; Malta; Mauritius; Mexico; Moldova; Mongolia; Morocco; Netherlands; New Zealand; North Macedonia; Norway; Oman; Peru; Portugal; Qatar; Republic of Ireland; Republic of Korea; Republic of Seychelles; Saudi Arabia; Serbia; Singapore; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain; Sri-Lanka; Sweden; Switzerland; Syria; Tajikistan; Thailand; Tunisia; Turkey; Turkmenistan; United States of America; Uzbekistan; Vietnam; Venezuela; United Arab Emirates; United Kingdom.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220405071920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

No changes. Mask-wearing, distance, general measures. Graduation celebrations are allowed. Recreational classes and excursions may take place with consent from the Ministry of Education.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No changes. Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed. All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. Recreational classes and excursions may take place with consent from the Ministry of Education and competent institutions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No changes. Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed. All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Up to 500 people are allowed to meet indoors or outdoors. Sports events may have spectators of up to 50% capacity in outdoor stadiums or 30% capacity in indoor arenas. Graduation celebrations are allowed. Events expecting over 500 people must get permission from the Crisis Response Team. Recreational classes and excursions may take place with consent from the Ministry of Education and competent institutions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No changes. Up to 500 people are allowed to meet indoors or outdoors. Events expecting over 500 people must get permission from the Crisis Response Team. Sports events may have spectators of up to 50% capacity in outdoor stadiums or 30% capacity in indoor arenas. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Mask-wearing. Anyone 2 years or older should properly wear a well-fitting mask in indoor public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402222514/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-4/coronavirus-serbia
No changes. The government recommends to reduce contact when possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307215735/https://covid19.rs/
No internal movement restrictions in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Starting December 20, 2020 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreigners seeking to enter Serbia will need to provide a negative PCR test, not older than 48 hours. These measures are reported to not apply to several categories of travelers, including:  Foreign citizens in transit, with 12 hours allowed between entry to and exit from Serbia.  Minors up to 12 years of age, provided the parent, custodian or any other person accompanying the minor has a negative PCR test, if it is needed.  Crew and cabin crew of aircraft whose final destination is Serbia.  Crew, personnel, and passengers in transit through Serbiaâs international airports.  Accredited staff of foreign diplomatic and consular missions, as well as offices of international organizations. Also included are family members with diplomatic status in Serbia. Foreign citizens who have been granted temporary residence or permanent residence in Serbia.  As of July 24, 2021 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreign citizens may enter Serbia without a negative COVID-19 test if they possess proof of recovery from COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their entry and no more than 6 months prior to their entry.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change.    A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of Â½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 eachâin May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn); and a one-off payment of EUR 25 to all vaccinated citizens (RSD 9 billion). The total estimated cost amounts to 2.5 percent of GDP. It also includes additional healthcare spending and increased public investment (2 percent of GDP), mostly in infrastructure, environmental protection, and defence. The existing scheme for state guaranteed bank loans to SMEs has been expanded by EUR 500 million (1 percent of GDP) and a new EUR 500 million scheme for vulnerable companies has been established.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In February 2021, the NBS and the ECB agreed to extend the duration of the precautionary repo line with the ECB to address possible euro liquidity needs of Serbian financial institutions. The repo line, initially planned to last until end-June 2021, has been extended for nine months, until end-March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In February 2021, the NBS and the ECB agreed to extend the duration of the precautionary repo line with the ECB to address possible euro liquidity needs of Serbian financial institutions. The repo line, initially planned to last until end-June 2021, has been extended for nine months, until end-March 2022 and as of the 10th of March 2022, the repo line has been extended further until the 15th of January 2023.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://archive.ph/MUowa
There is a coordinated public information campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307215735/https://covid19.rs/
PCR and antigen tests are available in Serbia.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220402221440/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/
No change. There seems to be some contact tracing in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220305115200/https://covid19.rs/homepage-english/

During their stay in public places indoors, citizens are obliged to wear protective masks and maintain a distance of at least two meters between two persons who do not reside in the same household, in order to prevent the spread of the infectious disease COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307222130/https://www.propisi.net/uredbu-o-merama-za-sprecavanje-i-suzbijanje-zarazne-bolesti-covid-19/    In public places in the open, if it is not possible to maintain a distance of at least two meters between two people (in front of shops, pharmacies, bus and other stops, etc.), wearing protective masks is mandatory. It is obligatory to wear protective masks in public road and rail transport of passengers. Parents of minor children or children with special needs, ie their guardians, are obliged to ensure that children older than four years wear a protective mask in the cases referred to in para. 1â3. of this article.

The obligation to wear a respirator at mass events remains in place, including outdoor mass events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321210725/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/

Schools are fully open.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325162927/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Workers in healthcare and social care institutions and in prisons are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Following easing of almost all restrictions on the 22nd of February, there is no longer any restrictions on public events taking place, though masks are recommended at outdoor events where 1.5m social distancing is not possible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

There is no longer a cap on the number of people allowed to gather, either in public or private  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

Fully open, with a mask mandate for all passengers over 6 years old and all drivers.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/
People who are ill are told to stay home. People who have come into close contact with a positive case are no longer required to quarantine
No restrictions in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

All travellers arriving in Slovenia will no longer be required to present proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test. All travellers arriving in Slovenia must continue to complete the Digital Passenger Locator Form 24 hours before arrival, if entering via an airport or a ferry terminal. The form is not required if entering overland at a border crossing.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/entry-requirements & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171842/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/

No policy change.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174611/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174715/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing is abolished. The government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required. Such activities include:  - Users of hospital and other healthcare services   - Persons who wish to discontinue their self-isolation between days 7 and 10 after testing positive  - Persons with proof of a positive rapid-antigen self-test result   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

A person who has tested positive in a coronavirus test is must inform all those with whom he or she has been in close contact.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Surgical mask II or IIR or a FFP2 or a FFP3 mask are mandatory in all closed public spaces and on public transport. Protective masks are recommended in open public spaces or outside if a distance of at least 1.5 metres is not possible to maintain.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/

1st April 2022 onwards, the remaining official recommendations will be removed or adapted to the rate of transmission, the burden on health care services, and vaccination rates at that time. After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

1st April 2022 onwards, the remaining official recommendations will be removed or adapted to the rate of transmission, the burden on health care services, and vaccination rates at that time. After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    Non-fully vaccinated travellers, e.g., unaccompanied minors, the partly vaccinated, or travellers with medical exemptions, are not exempted. The exemption is entirely connected to the vaccine certificate, not of country of residence or citizenship,    The list of approved countries in Sweden consists of:    Albania  Andorra  Armenia  Cabo Verde  El Salvador  Faroe Islands  Georgia  Israel  Lebanon  Morocco  Moldova  Monaco  Montenegro  New Zeeland  North Macedonia  Panama  San Marino  Serbia  Singapore  Switzerland  Taiwan  Thailand  Togo  Tunisia  Turkey  Ukraine  United Arab Emirates  The UK + Guernsey, Isle of Man and Jersey  Uruguay  USA  Vatican    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

A PCR test is required for individuals over the age of 12 years old who are unable to show proof of vaccination.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  COVID-19 control measures for air, land, and sea travel continue. Passengers arriving in Turkey?will be required to complete an information form and will be checked for symptoms. Passengers may be subject to a PCR test by means of the method of sampling at points of arrival in Turkey. Within this scope, these passengers shall be allowed to proceed to their final destination after their test samples are taken. If their test results are positive, they shall be taken under treatment in accordance with the COVID-19 Guidelines of the Ministry of Health. The passengers with positive test results and persons having been in close contact with such passengers shall be taken under quarantine for a period of 7 days at the addresses they have determined, and if the results of the PCR tests to be taken at the end of the 5th day are negative, the quarantine shall be ended. The quarantines of these people who are identified to have Delta variant shall be ended upon submitting a negative PCR test result at the end of the 7th day.  Passengers must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival, if arriving from or they have been in Afghanistan, South Africa, Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Brazil, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan in the last 14 days.    This does not apply to passengers younger than 12 years.  Passengers arriving from Egypt and Iran must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival.  This does not apply to passengers younger than 12 years.  Effective January 10, 2022, passengers arriving from a country other than above countries do not need to submit negative PCR /rapid antigen test if;   passengers younger than 12 years;  passengers with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival;  passengers with a COVID-19 recovery certificate issued at most 6 months before arrival;  merchant seamen.  Passengers arriving into Turkey may be subject to a random PCR test at their final destination in Turkey.    A completed âTraveler Entry Formâ must be presented at check-in and upon arrival. The form can be obtained at http://register.health.gov.tr.    Passengers could be subject to self-isolation for up to 14 days.    This does not apply to passenger with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival.
